faq.q1: Is 2 inches of mulch enough?
faq.a1: Often yes for appearance and moisture retention, especially as a refresh layer. For better weed suppression, many beds use closer to 3 inches, but you should still keep mulch thinner right at plant crowns and trunks. If weeds are the main issue, bed prep (weeding and edging) matters as much as depth (project dependent).
faq.q2: How much more mulch is 3 inches vs 2 inches?
faq.a2: About 50% more volume for the same area because 3 inches is 1.5 times the depth of 2 inches. For example, if 2 inches requires 2 cubic yards, 3 inches will be about 3 cubic yards for the same bed area (before buffers and settling).
faq.q3: Should I remove old mulch first?
faq.a3: Not always. If the old layer is thin and in good shape, you can top it up. If it is thick, matted, or mixed with soil and weeds, removing some can prevent excess buildup and improve air and water movement. Also consider whether old mulch has accumulated year after year to a depth that is no longer healthy for the plants.

guideRoofingShed.metaTitle: How many shingles for a shed roof?
guideRoofingShed.metaDescription: Estimate shingles for a shed roof by measuring roof area, converting to squares, then to bundles and adding waste.
guideRoofingShed.title: How many shingles for a shed roof?
guideRoofingShed.subtitle: Measure roof area, convert to squares, then to bundles-don't forget waste and starter strips.

intro.p1: Shed roofs are usually simple, which makes shingle estimating easier than complex houses. The key is to estimate the roof surface area you will actually cover, not just the shed floor footprint. Overhangs add area, and roof pitch increases the sloped surface compared to the flat footprint.
intro.p2: Once you have roof surface area, convert to squares (100 sq ft) and then to bundles based on your shingle product. Finally, add waste and make sure you also have the accessories that do not follow the same math (starter strip, underlayment, drip edge, ridge cap if applicable).

steps.s1: Measure roof length along the eave and the sloped rafter length (the distance from eave to ridge/high edge). If you only have footprint width and pitch, convert to sloped length using a pitch factor (project dependent).
steps.s2: Compute roof area: length x sloped width for each roof plane. Many shed roofs are one plane, but if yours has multiple planes or a gable section, estimate each plane and add them.
steps.s3: Convert area to squares: squares = (sq ft / 100). Keep planes separate if you want a tighter waste estimate on cut-heavy shapes.
steps.s4: Convert squares to bundles using the actual product spec. Many asphalt shingles are about 3 bundles per square, but it varies by brand/type, and starter and ridge products have their own coverage rules.
steps.s5: Add waste and round up. Around 10% is common for simple rectangles, but increase waste for lots of trim, many cut edges, or if you are learning the install. Rounding up is usually cheaper than stopping mid-job to buy one more bundle.

tips.t1: Plan the full system: starter strips, underlayment, drip edge, nails, and flashing details. Missing one accessory can stop the job even if you have the right number of bundles.
tips.t2: Pay attention to slope. Low-slope roofs may require special underlayment, specific shingle products, or a different roofing system. Always follow manufacturer requirements and local code (project dependent).
tips.t3: Include overhangs and any attached roof sections. Small roofs are sensitive to small measurement errors, so double-check dimensions before ordering.
tips.t4: Keep at least a little extra for repairs and for starter/ridge adjustments. Matching shingles later can be harder than storing one extra bundle (check return policy if you are unsure).

guideRoofingShed.quickIntro: Use this checklist to get a practical bundle count (and avoid the missing-accessory problem).

quick.q1: Measure roof surface area, not just shed footprint. Include overhangs, and use a pitch factor if you only have horizontal dimensions (project dependent).
quick.q2: Convert to squares: squares = (sq ft / 100). Keep each roof plane separate if you want a tighter waste estimate on cut-heavy shapes.
quick.q3: Convert squares to bundles using the packaging/spec for your shingles (often 3 bundles per square, but not always). Starter strip and ridge cap (if used) have separate coverage numbers.
quick.q4: Add waste and round up. Simple rectangles often use around 10%, but add more for lots of trim, multiple planes, penetrations, or first-time installs (project dependent).

faq.q1: How many bundles are in a square?
faq.a1: Many asphalt shingles are about 3 bundles per square, but it varies by product type, weight, and brand. Always confirm on the packaging or the spec sheet for the exact shingles you are buying, and remember that starter and ridge products have separate coverage numbers.
faq.q2: Do I estimate by footprint or roof surface area?
faq.a2: Use roof surface area (the sloped area you will actually cover). The footprint is smaller on any pitched roof, and using it will undercount shingles. Also include overhangs if they are being shingled.
faq.q3: How much waste should I add for a shed roof?
faq.a3: Simple rectangles often use around 10%. Add more if you have many cut edges, lots of trim details, roof penetrations, or multiple planes. If you are close to minimum purchase quantities, rounding up can be cheaper than being short and making a second run (project dependent).

guideFencePosts.metaTitle: How many fence posts do I need?
guideFencePosts.metaDescription: Estimate fence posts by counting corners and gates, then adding line posts based on spacing.
guideFencePosts.title: How many fence posts do I need?
guideFencePosts.subtitle: Count corners and gates first, then add line posts using your chosen spacing.

intro.p1: Fence posts are easy to undercount because the layout is not just a long straight line. Corners, ends, and gates each need dedicated posts in addition to your regular line posts, and those special posts are often larger and set deeper than the rest.
intro.p2: A reliable post count starts with a simple plan: sketch the fence, break it into straight runs, and decide your spacing based on the fence style or panel width. Then count posts run by run and make sure you understand which posts are shared (for example, a corner post serves two runs).

steps.s1: Draw the fence layout and list each straight run between corners, ends, and gates. Measure run lengths along the property line where the fence will actually sit.
steps.s2: Choose post spacing based on your fence type and manufacturer specs. Many fences use 6-8 ft on-center, but prebuilt panels often dictate the spacing more than preference (project dependent).
steps.s3: Count posts per run. A simple method is: number of spaces = ceiling(run length / spacing), then posts in that run = spaces + 1. If two runs meet at a corner, the corner post is shared, so do not double-count it.
steps.s4: Add special posts: one corner post at each corner, end posts at any run endpoints that are not corners, and any brace/terminal posts your fence design requires (some styles need bracing at ends and corners).
steps.s5: Add gate posts. Most gates use two posts, and heavy or wide gates may need larger posts, deeper footings, or additional bracing. Round up if your plan includes future gate changes or uncertain spacing.

tips.t1: Corner, end, and gate posts often carry more load than line posts. Many builds use larger posts and deeper holes at terminals, and that can also affect the amount of concrete you need (project dependent).
tips.t2: Measure spacing on-center and confirm the actual panel width if you are using prebuilt panels. Small differences (like 6 ft vs 6 ft 8 in) can change the post count over a long run.
tips.t3: Slopes change the build. Stepped fences and grade changes can increase the number of short sections, which can increase posts and waste. Plan where steps happen before you finalize spacing.
tips.t4: Check local rules for frost depth, minimum post embedment, and footing details. The right depth can matter more for longevity than the exact spacing, especially in windy areas.

faq.q1: What spacing should I use for fence posts?
faq.a1: Common spacing is 6-8 feet on-center, but the best spacing depends on panel size, wind load, fence height, and material. If you are using prebuilt panels, follow the panel width and the manufacturer guidance so everything fits without forcing odd gaps (project dependent).
faq.q2: Do corners share posts?
faq.a2: Yes. A corner generally uses one dedicated corner post, and both fence runs connect to that same post. You do not count separate end posts for each run at the corner, but you may still need special bracing depending on the fence style and local wind (project dependent).
faq.q3: How do gates affect post count?
faq.a3: A gate usually needs two posts. Heavy, wide, or cantilevered gates may require larger posts, deeper footings, metal posts, or additional bracing to prevent sag. Plan gate locations early because they often determine where corners/ends fall and can change the count for nearby line posts.

guideGravelTons.metaDescription: Convert cubic yards of gravel to tons using density, then round up for supplier delivery quantities.
guideGravelTons.title: Convert gravel yards to tons
guideGravelTons.subtitle: Tons = cubic yards x density-confirm the density with your supplier.

intro.p1: Some suppliers sell gravel by cubic yards, others by tons. The conversion depends on material density, which varies by gravel type, gradation, and moisture. That’s why two suppliers can give different tons for the same 'yard' estimate.
intro.p2: Use your cubic yard estimate, then use the supplier’s yards-to-tons conversion for the exact product you are buying whenever possible. Generic density numbers are fine for planning, but supplier conversions are the most reliable for ordering.

steps.s1: Estimate volume in cubic yards based on area and compacted depth (or use an existing yard estimate from a volume calculator).
steps.s2: Choose a density for your material (tons per cubic yard). If the supplier provides a conversion table for your product, use it.
steps.s3: Multiply: tons = cubic yards x density (conversion factor). Keep units consistent: short tons (2,000 lb) vs metric tonnes (1,000 kg).
steps.s4: Add a buffer for compaction, uneven grade, and edge loss. Bases are often compacted in lifts; the installed coverage can be smaller than the loose delivered volume.
steps.s5: Round up to match delivery increments and minimum loads. The practical order size is often driven by truck size and fees, not perfect math.

tips.t1: Wet material can weigh more than dry material—supplier conversions are the best source. Ask for the product name/gradation so you’re comparing the right material.
tips.t2: Different products (pea gravel, crushed stone, base rock) can have different densities. Don’t assume one conversion fits both base and top layers.
tips.t3: If you need exact tonnage for hauling limits, confirm the conversion before ordering and note whether the supplier uses short tons or metric tonnes.
tips.t4: Ordering slightly extra is usually cheaper than paying a second delivery fee and trying to match material later (especially for decorative stone).

guideGravelTons.quickIntro: Yards-to-tons is only as accurate as the density you use, so treat supplier conversions as the source of truth. When in doubt, ask your supplier which ton unit they quote and what moisture condition they assume.

quick.q1: Start with a cubic yard estimate based on compacted (installed) depth. If you're estimating multiple layers, keep each layer separate so you don't mix products and densities.
quick.q2: Use the supplier's conversion for your exact product whenever possible. Moisture and gradation can change weight, so generic "tons per yard" averages are best for planning only.
quick.q3: Confirm the unit: short tons (2,000 lb) vs metric tonnes (1,000 kg). If you're hauling, ask the supplier what they load you to and whether it's measured or assumed.
quick.q4: Add buffer and round to delivery increments or minimum loads. In practice, truck size and fees often matter more than perfect math.

faq.q1: How many tons are in a cubic yard of gravel?
faq.a1: It depends on the material. Many gravels fall around 1.2-1.5 tons per cubic yard, but the best answer is your supplier's conversion for the exact product you are buying (including typical moisture).
faq.q2: Why do supplier conversions differ?
faq.a2: Density varies by rock type, gradation, moisture, and how the material is measured. Suppliers often use their own tested conversion for each product, and they may also be quoting different units (short tons vs metric tonnes).
faq.q3: Should I use compacted depth or loose depth?
faq.a3: Use compacted (installed) depth for your project target. Then add a small buffer to account for compaction and uneven grade. If you are building a base course, expect compaction and lift placement to affect the final coverage (project dependent).

guideTopsoilLeveling.metaDescription: Estimate topsoil for leveling by using an average depth, converting volume to cubic yards, then adding buffer for low spots.
guideTopsoilLeveling.title: Topsoil for leveling a lawn
guideTopsoilLeveling.subtitle: Use an average depth to estimate, then add extra for low spots and settling.

tldr.t1: Use average depth (thin overall + deeper low spots).
tldr.t2: Convert volume to cubic yards, then round up to delivery quantities.
tldr.t3: Add buffer for settling and any areas you plan to fill deeper.

intro.p1: Lawn leveling usually means a thin layer over the whole area plus extra soil in low spots. That makes average depth the key assumption.
intro.p2: Pick a realistic average depth, convert to cubic yards, then add a buffer if you expect deeper fills in specific areas.

steps.s1: Measure the lawn area you're leveling (exclude beds and hardscape).
steps.s2: Choose an average depth (thin topdressing vs deeper fill for low spots).
steps.s3: Convert area x depth to volume (cubic feet/meters).
steps.s4: Convert volume to cubic yards for ordering.
steps.s5: Add buffer for low spots and settling, then round up.

tips.t1: For very uneven lawns, estimate topdressing and low-spot fill separately.
tips.t2: Soil settles after watering and rain-extra helps you finish without a second delivery.
tips.t3: A sand/soil blend can be easier to spread for leveling; confirm what's recommended for your grass type.
tips.t4: Avoid burying grass too deeply at once-level in multiple thin passes if needed.

guideTopsoilLeveling.quickIntro: Leveling is about averages. This checklist helps you avoid using one worst-case depth and ordering exactly the calculated volume with no margin. A practical approach is to plan a thin blanket layer across the whole lawn, then estimate low spots separately. Even small depth changes add up quickly across a large area.

quick.q1: Measure only the area you will level (exclude beds and hardscape). Break the lawn into rectangles so you don't miss strips near fences or along paths. If the yard has distinct zones, estimate each zone separately so small areas don't distort the total.
quick.q2: Choose an average depth: thin topdressing across most of the lawn plus extra in low spots. Take a few depth readings in highs and lows and use a realistic average instead of one maximum number. For low spots, estimate their area and the extra depth beyond the blanket layer, then add that volume on top.
quick.q3: Convert inches to feet before multiplying, then convert cubic feet to cubic yards (divide by 27). If using bags, convert using bag volume and round up because you can't buy partial bags. If you work in metric, convert to cubic meters first and then to whatever unit your supplier sells.
quick.q4: Add buffer for settling, spread loss, and low spots you discover while raking. Plan for wheelbarrow/spillage loss and for the reality that you often find new lows after the first pass. If you're building up more than about an inch, consider leveling in multiple thin passes so you don't smother grass (project dependent).

mistakes.m1: Using maximum depth everywhere instead of an average depth.
mistakes.m2: Forgetting settling/compaction and ordering exactly the calculated number.
mistakes.m3: Trying to level too much in one pass and stressing the grass.

guideTopsoilLeveling.ctaBody: Use our topsoil calculator and share a link that keeps your inputs.

faq.q1: How deep should topsoil be for leveling?
faq.a1: Many leveling projects use a thin layer (around 1/4"-1") across most of the lawn, with deeper fill in low spots. Choose an average depth that matches your plan.
faq.q2: Should I use topsoil, sand, or a mix?
faq.a2: It depends on your lawn and goals. Many leveling jobs use a sand/soil mix for easier spreading. Local guidance can help you choose.
faq.q3: How much extra should I order?
faq.a3: Add a buffer if you have noticeable low spots or expect settling. Extra soil also helps avoid a second delivery.

buyingTips.b1: Buy enough from the same batch to avoid color variation.

faq.q1: How do I calculate paint for a wall?
faq.a1: Measure each wall's width x height and subtract large openings (windows/doors) if you want a tighter estimate.
faq.q2: What coverage should I use?
faq.a2: Many interior paints cover around 300-400 sq ft per gallon per coat. Use the product label when possible.
faq.q3: Should I add extra paint (waste/overage)?
faq.a3: Extra paint helps account for texture, roller loss and touch-ups.

faq.q1: Should I subtract doors and windows?

faq.q2: What waste factor should I use for wallpaper?
faq.a2: Waste varies by pattern matching, corners, and cuts. 10% is a common starting point; increase it for complex layouts or patterned wallpaper.
faq.q3: Why is the roll count rounded up?

faq.q2: Do I need to subtract cabinets or closets?

faq.q2: How do I find coverage per box?
faq.a2: Use the product label or retailer listing; coverage depends on tile size and pieces per box.
faq.q3: Why are boxes rounded up?
faq.a3: You can only buy whole boxes, and extra helps with breakage and future repairs.

faq.q1: What is deck mud?
faq.a1: Deck mud (dry pack mortar) is a sand-and-cement mix used for mortar beds, often for shower pans and tile underlayment.
faq.q2: How do I calculate deck mud coverage (sq ft)?
faq.a2: Deck mud is a volume estimate: volume (cu ft) = area (sq ft) x thickness (in) / 12. If the bed is sloped (common for showers), thickness is not uniform-use an average thickness, then add a buffer for waste and cleanup.
faq.q3: What mix ratio should I use for deck mud (dry pack)?
faq.a3: Many mixes use 5:1 sand-to-cement by volume as a starting point, but systems vary. Follow your waterproofing/drain system guidance and local practice for minimum thickness and mix requirements (project dependent).

drywall.metaDescription: Estimate how many drywall sheets (sheetrock) you need from area, sheet size, and a waste factor.

drywall.subtitle: Estimate how many drywall sheets you need. Adjust sheet coverage for 4x8, 4x10, or 4x12.

faq.q1: How many drywall sheets (sheetrock) do I need?
faq.a1: Start with total wall/ceiling area, divide by sheet coverage (32, 40, or 48 sq ft), then add a waste factor and round up to whole sheets.
faq.q2: What waste factor should I use?
faq.a2: 10-15% is common depending on cuts and layout.
faq.q3: Does this include screws or joint compound?
faq.a3: No. This estimates sheets only.

drywallTexture.metaDescription: Estimate drywall texture material (bags) based on area, coats, coverage, and a waste factor.

faq.q1: How do I estimate drywall texture?
faq.a1: Multiply area by coats/passes, divide by product coverage per bag, add waste, then round up.
faq.q2: What coverage per bag should I use?
faq.a2: Use the exact product label. Coverage varies by texture type and application method.
faq.q3: How much waste should I add?
faq.a3: 5-15% is common. Spraying, sanding, and learning curves can increase waste.

concrete.title: Concrete Calculator
concrete.subtitle: Estimate cubic yards for a slab. Add a waste factor and optional price per cubic yard.

faq.q1: How do I calculate cubic yards of concrete for a slab?
faq.a1: Convert thickness to feet, then cubic feet = length (ft) x width (ft) x thickness (ft). Cubic yards = cubic feet / 27. Example: 10 ft x 10 ft x 4" is about 1.23 yd³ before waste (project dependent).
faq.q2: What thickness is typical for a concrete slab?
faq.a2: Many patios and walkways use around 4 inches, while driveways and heavier loads often use more. Your base prep, rebar/mesh design, and local requirements can change thickness (project dependent).
faq.q3: How much extra concrete should I order?
faq.a3: Many projects add 5-10% to cover uneven subgrade, spillage, and finishing losses. Also consider delivery minimums: coming up short can be more expensive than a small overage.

mulch.metaDescription: Estimate mulch volume in cubic yards/meters from bed area and depth, with a buffer for settling and uneven spots.
mulch.title: Mulch Calculator
mulch.subtitle: Estimate cubic yards of mulch based on bed area and depth.

faq.q1: What mulch depth is typical?
faq.a1: Many beds use 2-4 inches. Follow plant and climate recommendations.
faq.q2: How do I calculate cubic yards of mulch?
faq.a2: Cubic yards = area (sq ft) x depth (in) / 324. Example: 500 sq ft at 3" depth is about 4.63 yd³ before waste. If you're ordering in bulk, round up to match delivery minimums (project dependent).
faq.q3: Should I add extra mulch?
faq.a3: Usually yes. Mulch settles after spreading and watering, and bed edges/low spots use more material than a perfectly flat rectangle. 5-10% is a common buffer.

roofing.metaDescription: Shingle bundle calculator: estimate shingles from roof area, waste factor and coverage per bundle, with optional cost.
roofing.title: Roofing Calculator
roofing.subtitle: Estimate shingles using squares and bundles. Adjust waste and bundle coverage.

faq.q1: What is a roofing square?
faq.a1: A roofing square is 100 square feet of roof area.
faq.q2: How many bundles are in a square (100 sq ft)?
faq.a2: Often about 3 bundles per square, but it depends on product type and exposure. Use the packaging/spec sheet for your exact shingles.
faq.q3: Why add waste?
faq.a3: Cuts, valleys, hips and mistakes require extra shingles.

deck.metaDescription: Deck estimator: estimate deck boards needed based on deck size, board dimensions, gap, board length and a waste factor.
deck.title: Deck Board Calculator
deck.subtitle: Estimate deck boards. Adjust board width, gap, length and a waste factor.

faq.q1: Does this deck calculator include joists or framing?
faq.a1: No. This deck board calculator estimates decking boards only; framing (joists, beams, posts) is a separate estimate.
faq.q2: How do I estimate deck boards more accurately?
faq.a2: Board length choice and seam layout affect waste. If you have a picture-frame border, diagonal layout, lots of notches around posts, or stairs, use a higher waste factor and treat those features as separate line items when possible.
faq.q3: What gap and waste factor are typical?
faq.a3: Many decks use a small gap (often around 1/8 in) for drainage and expansion. Waste is often 5-10% for simple rectangles and higher for diagonal layouts, borders, lots of cuts, or stairs (project dependent).

fence.metaDescription: Fence calculator: estimate fence panels and posts from length, spacing, panel width, and a waste factor. Adjust for corners and gates.
fence.title: Fence Calculator (Panels & Posts)
fence.subtitle: Estimate panels and posts for a straight fence line. Adjust waste and optional costs.

faq.q1: How are fence posts estimated?
faq.a1: Posts are estimated using your spacing along the length, plus an end post. Real projects usually need extra posts for corners, ends, and both sides of each gate.
faq.q2: Do I need to adjust for corners or gates?
faq.a2: Yes-corners, ends and gates may add additional posts and hardware, and gate posts may need to be stronger depending on gate size and wind load (project dependent).
faq.q3: What spacing is common?
faq.a3: Many fence panels are 8 ft, with posts spaced accordingly. Follow local code and product specs.

gravel.metaDescription: Estimate gravel (crushed stone) in cubic yards from area, depth, and waste, with optional cost.
gravel.title: Gravel Calculator
gravel.subtitle: Estimate cubic yards of gravel based on area and depth.

quick.t1: Measure length x width (or total area) in feet or meters.
quick.t2: Use a realistic depth (many projects are 2-6 inches).
quick.t3: Add a small buffer for compaction and uneven base.

howToMeasure.s1: For rectangles: area = length x width. For circles: area = pi x r².
howToMeasure.s2: Break irregular shapes into rectangles, add them, and round up slightly.
howToMeasure.s3: Convert depth to feet (in / 12) or meters (cm / 100).

assumptions.a1: Depth is average depth after grading (low spots can increase volume).
assumptions.a2: Material type affects density; supplier conversions (yards <-> tons) vary.
assumptions.a3: Compaction can reduce loose volume-buffers help avoid a second delivery.

buyingTips.b1: Confirm whether your supplier sells by yards, tons, or bags.
buyingTips.b2: Ask for a recommended depth for your application (driveway, path, base).
buyingTips.b3: Round up to delivery minimums and keep a small amount for touch-ups.

faq.q1: What gravel depth should I use?
faq.a1: It depends on the application. Many paths and beds use a few inches, while driveways and base layers often need more depth and proper compaction. Use an average finished depth and follow local/supplier recommendations (project dependent).
faq.q2: How do I calculate cubic yards of gravel?
faq.a2: Cubic yards = area (sq ft) x depth (in) / 324. For irregular shapes, break the area into rectangles, add them up, then use the same formula and round up slightly.
faq.q3: How much extra gravel should I order?
faq.a3: A small buffer helps cover compaction, grading variation, and delivery minimums. If you have lots of edges, transitions, or low spots, consider a higher buffer (project dependent).

sand.metaDescription: Estimate sand volume in cubic yards/meters and convert to tons/tonnes using density presets, with optional cost.

sand.subtitle: Estimate sand volume and weight based on area, depth, and density.

faq.q1: Should I buy sand by cubic yards or tons?
faq.a1: Both are common. If your supplier sells by tons, use a realistic density preset (dry/packed/wet) to convert volume to weight.
faq.q2: Why does sand weight vary?
faq.a2: Moisture content and compaction change density. Wet or packed sand can weigh more per cubic yard.
faq.q3: What waste factor should I use?
faq.a3: Many projects use 5-10% to cover compaction, uneven base, and small measuring errors. If you're filling low spots or working with irregular edges, use a higher buffer (project dependent).

faq.a2: No. Bedding sand is a thin leveling layer. The compacted base stone provides structure and drainage.

faq.q1: Is 50/50 compost and topsoil a good mix?
faq.a1: It's a common starting point for raised beds because it balances organic matter with structure, but ideal mixes vary by plants, climate, and drainage. Use it as a baseline, then adjust based on how your soil holds water and how your plants respond (project dependent).
faq.q2: Should I include sand in a soil mix?
faq.a2: Sometimes. Sand is often used in leveling mixes and in certain drainage-focused blends, but adding sand to the wrong native soil can create an undesirable texture. Use sand intentionally (for a specific purpose) and follow local guidance for your plants and soil type (project dependent).
faq.q3: Why add a waste factor?
faq.a3: Soil can settle after watering and compaction, and it's easy to under-measure. A small buffer helps you avoid shortages.

faq.q2: Should I use nominal or actual size?

faq.a1: It depends on your area and bag size. A shortcut is: coverage per bag (sq ft) = bag volume (cu ft) / (depth in / 12). For example, a 2 cu ft bag covers about 12 sq ft at 2" depth (about 8 sq ft at 3"); a 3 cu ft bag covers about 18 sq ft at 2" (about 12 sq ft at 3"). Enter your exact area/depth and round up.
faq.q2: What is the most common bag size?
faq.a2: Many stores sell 2 cu ft and 3 cu ft bags. Always confirm the bag label.
faq.q3: Should I add waste?
faq.a3: Yes. Mulch settles after spreading and watering, and beds are rarely perfectly flat. 5-10% is a common buffer.

faq.q2: Why do different bag sizes give different results?

faq.q3: Should I add waste?

faq.a2: Use the stock length you plan to buy (commonly 8 ft or 12 ft). The calculator rounds up to whole pieces.
faq.q3: How much waste should I add?
faq.a3: 5-10% is common. Add more for lots of corners, complex rooms, or if you're new to trim work.

faq.q1: How many bags of topsoil do I need?
faq.a1: Enter your area and average depth, pick your bag size, and the calculator will round up to whole bags. A helpful conversion: 1 cubic yard = 27 cubic feet, so a 2 cu ft bag is about 0.074 yd³ (label volume varies by brand).
faq.q2: What depth should I use?
faq.a2: It depends on the project (leveling vs planting). Use an average depth and consider adding waste for uneven spots.
faq.q3: Should I buy bagged or bulk topsoil?
faq.a3: Bagged topsoil is convenient for small projects. For larger volumes, bulk delivery can be cheaper.

faq.q1: Why does yards-to-tons conversion vary?
faq.a1: It depends on density, which changes with gravel type, moisture, and compaction. As a rough idea, many gravels fall in the ~1.3-1.6 tons per cubic yard range, but your supplier may use a different conversion (project dependent).
faq.q2: Should I round up?
faq.a2: Usually yes. Delivery minimums and compaction can make you come up short if you order too tightly.
faq.q3: Should I use tons or tonnes?
faq.a3: In the US, suppliers often use short tons. In many other markets, metric tonnes are common. Use whatever your supplier quotes.

faq.a1: Follow tile and spacing recommendations. Wider joints use more grout.
faq.q2: Is sanded or unsanded grout better?
faq.a2: It depends on joint width and tile type. Use the product guidelines for your application.
faq.q3: Should I add waste?
faq.a3: Yes. Spillage, cleanup, and uneven joints can increase usage. 5-10% is a common buffer.

faq.a1: It's a planning estimate based on average seam density for a sheet size and your chosen assumptions. Corners and real layouts can change material needs.
faq.q2: Why does sheet size matter?
faq.a2: Larger sheets generally create fewer seams per square foot, which reduces tape and compound.
faq.q3: How many coats should I use?
faq.a3: Many finishing approaches use multiple coats. Choose what matches your plan and product recommendations.

topsoil.metaDescription: Topsoil calculator in cubic yards: estimate topsoil volume from area, depth and waste factor, with optional cost.

quick.t1: Measure total area and choose an average depth for the project.
quick.t2: Convert depth to feet or meters before calculating volume.
quick.t3: Add a small buffer for settling, grading, and uneven areas.

howToMeasure.s1: For rectangles: area = length x width. For circles: area = pi x r².
howToMeasure.s2: For lawns, measure sections and add them for total area.
howToMeasure.s3: Convert depth to feet (in / 12) or meters (cm / 100).

assumptions.a1: Use average depth-topdressing and leveling often vary across the area.
assumptions.a2: If you're filling low spots, include extra volume for those areas.
assumptions.a3: Bulk topsoil may settle; a buffer prevents running short.

buyingTips.b1: Confirm whether you need screened topsoil for a smoother finish.
buyingTips.b2: Round up to delivery minimums and keep a small amount for touch-ups.
buyingTips.b3: If you add compost, adjust the mix ratio and volume accordingly.

faq.q1: What topsoil depth is typical?
faq.a1: It depends on the project. Many lawns use a thin layer; raised beds often use more.
faq.q2: Why cubic yards (yd³)?
faq.a2: Bulk topsoil is commonly sold by the cubic yard. Convert area and average depth to cubic feet, then divide by 27 to get cubic yards (yd³).
faq.q3: Should I add waste?
faq.a3: A buffer helps account for settling and uneven areas.
